Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Modular And Reconfigurable Electromagnetic Navigation System For Surgical Interventions And Medical Robotics
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a novel electromagnetic navigation system that offers a transformative solution for a wide range of medical procedures that demand accuracy, efficiency, and safety. The result of this capability and its subsequent commercialization will positively affect the outcomes of medical procedures for patients worldwide. The system will enable tracking medical instruments over the full procedure space, improve accuracy and reliability, and reduce patient and staff exposure to harmful radiation while being compatible with the intraoperative imaging. It will create and augment navigation volumes on demand during the medical procedures. The system will enable reliable detection and mitigation of electromagnetic interference. The commercial and market potential of this solution is significant based on customer discovery interviews with industry representatives seeking novel electromagnetic navigation capabilities for minimally invasive and robotic medical procedures. The broader societal impacts of the technology offer flexible and highly customizable platforms across key industry sectors important to United States competitiveness including biomedical, consumer, industrial, and defense sectors. <br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance the development of a new electromagnetic navigation system that requires solving several complex problems involving mathematics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Millions of minimally invasive procedures are performed annually worldwide which include cardiac ablations, valve replacements, bronchoscopies, orthopedic procedures, cancer treatments, etc. All of these procedures are being treated with increasing robot utilization. Electromagnetic navigation systems are widely used in these procedures providing knowledge of locations and orientations when medical instruments are out of the “line of sight”. Currently available systems, developed before the wide adoption of robotic surgeries, can handle only fixed navigation volumes and are often unable to track instruments throughout the full procedure space, which may require the use of additional harmful X-ray radiation. The current systems use bulky field generators incompatible with imaging equipment and provide only limited detection and correction of electromagnetic interference-induced location distortion in the body. This project will address these shortcomings. It leverages the industry expertise and demand validation by leading companies in the minimally invasive and robotics markets, the efficiency and innovation of an experienced team, and a functional electromagnetic navigation system prototype developed by the company.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview.

Radwave Technologies Inc. is creating an electromagnetic navigation system that meets the demands of advanced minimally invasive procedures and robotic surgeries. Millions of minimally invasive surgical procedures are performed annually worldwide which include cardiac ablations, valve replacements, bronchoscopies, orthopedic procedures, cancer treatments, etc., all with increasing robot utilization. Electromagnetic tracking (also called navigation) systems are widely used in minimally invasive procedures for tracking medical instruments, providing knowledge of positions and orientations when there is no "line of sight". An example of the electromagnetic tracking application to navigating a catheter during a minimally invasive or robotic procedure is shown Fig. 1, in which the electromagnetic field generating antenna is placed under the patient?s body, available tracking volume is shown in green. Radwave Technologies is working on bringing to the market the new electromagnetic tracking system which will overcome limitations of small tracking volumes and distortions caused by metal interference present in the currently available systems. 

The new system will enable tracking of medical instruments over the entire patient's volume, improve accuracy and reliability, and reduce patients and medical staff exposure to harmful radiation while being compatible with the imaging equipment. Creating such a system requires solving a number of complex problems involving mathematics, computer science and electrical engineering for aggregating signals from multiple sources and performing complex computations for tracking medical instruments and detecting and correcting interference in real time. This project leverages the industry expertise and demand validation by leading companies in the minimally invasive and robotics market, the efficiency and innovation of an experienced team, and a functional electromagnetic navigation system prototype developed by the company.

Project outcomes.

The primary objectives for the Phase I project were to demonstrate technical feasibility of procedure-time navigation volume reconfigurability, demonstrate metal and electromagnetic interference detection and mitigation leveraging the unique capabilities of the Radwave electromagnetic tracking system, and test the system in realistic clinical environment. Phase I work was performed using the new tracking system prototype. The prototype control unit is shown in Fig 2, the field generating antenna is shown in Fig. 3. The Radwave team has successfully accomplished all Phase I tasks. During this project, we have accomplished the following objectives:

  a. Demonstrated the feasibility of navigation volume extension and accurate localization in the extended volume.

  b. Demonstrated the feasibility of robust distortion detection.

  c. Demonstrated interference detection using the Radwave electromagnetic tracking platform with no tracking sensors necessary.

 d. Developed and demonstrated the effectiveness of several distortion mitigation strategies, which could be combined to provide a reliable tracking even in challenging environments with various distorters, such as hospital beds, C-arms and various medical instruments around sensors.

e. The system was evaluated in clinical environments for tracking accuracy and interference detection/mitigation capabilities.

During the Phase I work, we started a partnership with TT Electronics, a global electronics manufacturer, which is supplying sensors for the Radwave system and is a contract manufacturer for Radwave control unit and field generating antennas.

The current prototype loaded with latest algorithms and software is marketed as an integrable navigation system and was purchased by several early customers for evaluation and further integration with their medical devices aimed at a wide range of minimally invasive procedures. These customers represent medical robotics, electrophysiology, interventional radiology, and other sectors.

Based on the outcomes of this project, research papers and patent applications are being prepared.

Modified by: Lev Koyrakh
